variant.footnote: 5This label differs from the normal SUBJ in that it is object case, as in 'He saw her leave.' 6This relation links an extracted word with the verb before which it occurs, e.g. the first two words in 'What do you think he said?' (Hudson, 1990, p. 192).
variant.figure: she may have been examined by now PMOD MODAL SUBJ PERFECT POBJ PASSIVE DIROBJ CONJ SUBJ DET CONJ DET she bought a card and a flower DIROBJ BELCLAUSE SUBJ PASSIVE SUBJ DET DIROBJ DET POBJ I found the address to which the mail was delivered Conclusions
variant.bodyText: We describe a comprehensive, implemented, de- pendency grammar of English, using 14 part- of-speech categories, 26 relation types, and 168 constraints on the combinations of these. It is work-in-progress and, in particular, the neces- sary lexicon for evaluating against a large cor- pus (the Penn Treebank) has not been finished.
Kilian Foth has given much help with the gram- mar development, and Wolfgang Menzel com- mented on a draft version of the paper.
variant.reference: Creswell, C. and Rambow, 0.: 2003, English Dependency Treebank Coding Manual, http://www.cis.upenn.edu/-creswell/ dependency/. Foth, K., Hamerich, S., Schröder, I., Schulz, M. and By, T.: 2003, IX1CDG User guide, Fach- bereich Informatik, Universitat Hamburg. Hays, D. G.: 1964, Dependency Theory: A Formalism and Some Observations, Language 40(4), 511-525. Hudson, R.: 1990, English Word Grammar, Basil Blackwell Ltd. Mel'euk, I. A. and Pertsov, N. V.: 1987, Surface Syntax of English, John Benjamins. Quirk, R., Greenbaum, S., Leech, G. and Svartvik, J.: 1985, A Comprehensive Gram- mar of the English Language, Longman, Lon- don. Rambow, 0., Cresswell, C., Szekely, R., Tar- ber, H. and Walker, M.: 2002, A Depen- dency Treebank for English, Third Interna- tional Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation, pp. 857-863. Schroeder, I., Menzel, W., Foth, K. and Schulz, M.: 2000, Modeling dependency grammar with restricted constraints, Traitement au- tomatique des langues.

variant.abstract: I found the address to which the mail was delivered Conclusions We describe a comprehensive, implemented, dependency grammar of English, using 14 partof-speech categories, 26 relation types, and 168 constraints on the combinations of these. It is work-in-progress and, in particular, the necessary lexicon for evaluating against a large corpus (the Penn Treebank) has not been finished.
variant.title: Acknowledgements
variant.author: Kilian Foth has given much help with the grammar development
Wolfgang Menzel com-
